5903A059ABCA4483B3606CD69C3D6CD6.description: Research provincial and community arts organizations as resources to make connections within communities.

BCB33DCB664043E78E708B966556DF3F.description: Engage with artists on collaborative projects through such means as artists in schools or artist in communities’ programs.

BC4197899E484F72A23E09540DCC8088.description: Investigate artist collectives, alternative gallery environments, artist run centers, or studentrun art pop-up center, and consider opportunities to volunteer in own community.

13479011F80E4EBC9D92DEB89BD4C001.description: Examine issues often encountered by visual artists (e.g., protecting own and others’ intellectual property, copyright, cultural appropriation of images, music, fashion) and ways of addressing these issues.

2C7AB3A069D64721A88186F91C33DC43.description: Use technology to connect with community (e.g., website, social media) to further own development in visual art.

DDE93F44E3A94256A6A3816F019B35DB.description: Discuss opportunities and challenges of working in various visual arts careers.

E509E0F26A2D4BDCAB78B39D9E4A9D94.description: Research artists and examine examples of artist biographies, resumes and artist statements as exemplars for own art practice.

C5614CA5F5144B60B152CD7C27CAE70E.description: Examine visual art careers and opportunities to learn from individuals who work in the arts sector (e.g., participate in Work Study* experiences with professional associations, provincial and community arts and cultural organizations; independent study mentorships with individual artists or collectives)

C752E6D1A5EE422AB48CD49BF23E6152.description: Interact with other classrooms, professional artists, art shows or community events to improve own growth.

6B44D694634E4AD1ACF707EEDBD669E5.description: Engage with communities to collaborate and build relationships beyond the classroom through visual art experiences.

9CCD068A6D144CBBB7630101D307CDFB.description: Examine how visual art, and the other arts, contribute to personal and social wellbeing in communities (e.g., fostering connections, sharing stories, creating empathy).

1B3565A04A5645C4A93E9599D82CF042.description: Examine various approaches to communicate (e.g., humour, story, irony, satire, metaphor, symbol, using beauty to depict challenging subject matter) and respond visually in ways that can influence perspectives and contribute to change in communities and societies.

78E5A71E41244EFCB62B6688CFAA3C23.description: Investigate how artists from various cultural backgrounds draw on their historical traditions in different ways as contemporary art practices evolve over time.

A58A627E763F49E8B26638BE3C8428F0.description: Examine the influence of the evolution of digital media on the creation of art expressions.

4D7719CE97CD47CBA43D7BD9C8A35EF5.description: Research key changes in art and design throughout history (e.g., furniture, jewelry, architecture, functional art, fashion, album covers).

8DBE072841AA4DF4BDFEC2856EE25F0C.description: Examine how visual art expressions have changed over time and/or inspired change in individuals, communities and societies.

84E1A5C2121B4F65BD5494214C52BF52.description: Examine, respect and honour traditional, historical and contemporary connections to the land and the natural world (e.g., treaty education outcome TPP12 - represent personal understanding of the concept, We Are All Treaty People).

4F012B6FE7044D98B2F86671476BF4A4.description: Research and share findings about the work of contemporary Indigenous artists and curators in Canada.

649A7BA8FAAD4C2ABDC94D5941676B66.description: Use research, discussions, experiences and ideas about treaties as inspiration for creating own work (e.g., treaty education outcome SI122 - investigate the values and beliefs of self, family, community, and society in relation to the importance of honouring the Spirit and Intent of treaties).

68960113E40E467DAE8AAC48C95C93F8.description: Examine issues surrounding cultural appropriation and stereotypes (e.g., images, sports logos).

9B51348968A64F3D90ED115ED96DFBCF.description: Conduct an inquiry into how some art works and images promote stereotypes while other art works represent the truth and lived experiences of First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples.

57C76328F6F64D77A10D3451122AB2AF.description: Discuss the meaning of We are all Treaty People, considering its importance for Saskatchewan’s First Nations, Métis and non-Indigenous peoples.

07D11208F8E54B9B8CC1596529D59131.description: Analyze and communicate how artists have responded to colonization.

444DFEA36B56404BAE44FAF7C9009697.description: Engage with Elders and/or community members to gain understanding of ways that visual art in Canada can support relationship building.

A9AFBF135AB941648944D7A3E523DD41.description: Investigate how visual art in Canada can support and build relationships and deepen understanding that we are all treaty people.

241BEA46EE8C41EA8D75074519FADCCD.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) Goal: Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts, and understand the connection between the arts and the human experience.

44319E4858394DBDA9440DF65CBFCF33.description: Conduct an investigation into the connections between place, territory and/or identity (e.g., research Canadian artists whose work reflects a sense of place and identity).

7CD4336FDE4441C6B4F9931A0A6ED8BF.description: Investigate Indigenous perspectives and ways of knowing to appreciate sources of inspiration (e.g., memory, history, story) and range of artistic styles, and describe how personal worldview, voice and style are demonstrated in own artistic development.

B2A6311ED5E2498EB0E8787D47E5C5A1.description: Search for inspiration through a variety of sources (e.g., music, fashion, other artists) to extend ideas and techniques to apply to future works.

F689956775F949B0BEE80218A61EDF5A.description: Examine artistic influences and describe the impact of those influences on own work.

4070796D7D6C4E749585DA5F8E248750.description: Discuss how groups within societies have determined definitions of art throughout history leading to the exclusion or inclusion of specific voices (e.g., How have artists, minorities and their allies challenged definitions of art and promoted inclusion of diverse voices?).

3B27B535266744A99F12550036D69C8A.description: Document how an artist develops a style and voice over time including development of cultural, Western and personal narratives.

5DB274AE56924DE09A2069C98A6F07D0.description: Document and assess personal development in the creative process

816B179F3E564A2F86992C0C0D2173D2.description: Research, deconstruct, and discuss various approaches to the creative process and apply that understanding to own work.

E37431B418BB409E8AF8F42909045B0D.description: Explain, using visual art terminology, how one’s portfolio is demonstrating ideas, style and voice (e.g., How is the work related to a big idea?).

AD36F3C1CED94545B869158CCA6F6680.description: Reflect on own work and select examples to include in a portfolio (e.g., documentation of creative process, sketches showing idea development, photos of works in progress and resolved, collection of various techniques or different media).

FF131E06F33446EB91EB50244C199477.description: Review and discuss portfolios (e.g., own and peers, physical folder or digital collection) and write artist biographies and statements for individual works and/or a series of works.

EE885D9541CC430D868A7CFC277919CE.description: Critically reflect on choice of discipline, content and media in the development of own voice and style.

04D2A9FB37E540C2BA496FA3E08A202F.description: Use one or more approaches for responding critically to the visual art examples studied (e.g., write a formal critique or research paper using proper format including citations, create own work in response).

0437E0C7584842128B4DF3DAEC2A80B9.description: Discuss how concerns about the abuse of power are represented in works by Canadian artists (e.g., subject matter related to anti-racism, environmental sustainability, gender equity, political cartoons, comic book illustrations).

2CCF42683FDC459DB8E952587926F9DC.description: Respond to traditional and evolving work of First Nation, Métis and Inuit artists whose subject matter speaks to experiences of resistance and resilience (e.g., Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls art works and projects, treaty education outcome TR12 - examine one’s position regarding the importance of the treaty relationship for the social, cultural and economic prosperity of all Saskatchewan and Canadian people.).

807B6DAD3E1048468F4231E6637CD997.description: Examine how artists over time, and in various parts of the world, have responded to events involving acts of resistance and demonstrations of resilience (e.g., visual documentation of wars and genocide, African apartheid, Latin American artists’ responses to political injustices).

8C2A156476934031A00FB9CBBE1DC6CD.description: Conduct an inquiry into how art works can be acts, or representations, of resistance and resilience (e.g., What is the relationship between art and resistance and resilience? Does art have power to inspire social and political change? How does art contribute to individual or collective resilience? How can art-making support mental health and wellness?).

BE26DDA16E9C4EF88A73C120ECA2551B.description: Critically respond to art work by Canadian artists whose subject matter is related to resistance and/or resilience.

0163AD59DCEF4B8E84D3BD68FF9DC485.description: Discuss the use of image development strategies in the creation and expression of various artists’ voice, style and art-making contexts, including strategies

CCF297E37524402E9654A388401F77B8.description: Analyze how technical skills, design components and strategies (e.g., elements of art, principles of design, juxtaposition, exaggeration) have been used/manipulated in art work.

91E3963740194F5B843B15553371B2C8.description: Consider feedback from peers, teachers, and mentors and provide a rationale for how the visual art work was resolved.

14F877C361204630B24CC4FB543BB31F.description: Provide criterion-referenced feedback on peers’ work in a constructive manner, incorporating visual art terminology.

A1BDC7C508624F868AB0040C7D68C359.description: Collaborate with peers to co-construct assessment criteria (e.g., technical skills, compositional qualities, use of images) for reflection on the development and resolution of own work, and identify what will be used as evidence of learning (e.g., journals, sketchbooks, artist’s statements, video documentation, critiques, portfolios).

C0DB65046D4F48218E82006EF639DA5F.description: Identify criteria that are most appropriate to a particular form or style of art and apply when critiquing (e.g., functional designed object versus urban street art).

EC3572270C4E49298F6A8EA525DA2A6E.description: Examine own and others’ art works to reinforce the importance of context when developing criteria (e.g., collaborate with a beadwork artist to identify criteria for critique).

E40101B72B7343C8A606283569B36409.description: Collaborate with peers, teachers, and/or mentors to generate and apply appropriate contextual criteria for a critique of an art work.

0DA5729EE6694D7DAC2B44C1746320A2.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

C552B8075CBC48258573828FA531BE42.description: Contribute to a visual art project to raise awareness about a socially-relevant topic (e.g., dedicated commemorative days and special events, public art installation, community arts events, artist in residence projects).

98ED3057F30B498CB015A8255FDAB16A.description: Discuss how own art work reflects personal experiences and identity (e.g., newcomer experiences, cultural ways of knowing, personal wellness, gender and sexual diversity).

FCF2D826CDAC43FBBD4041E4E55B1E3C.description: Create an art work based on individual or collaborative inquiry, including for example: generating questions for inquiry about the social issues reflected in the work of Canadian artists (e.g., How do art works influence change? How can art raise awareness about environmental, social and economic sustainability issues?), comparing and contrasting the work of Canadian artists, researching and viewing works of recognized Canadian artists, experimenting with techniques and media used by Canadian artists and documenting inquiry through own art work • sharing inquiry findings or learnings with others (e.g., classmates, school, community).

0F5CA9BB06AE49A582B8FD417C8C4D9C.description: Use inquiry to create art work inspired by Canadian artists whose work responds to sociallyrelevant topics (e.g., sustainability, social justice, diversity and inclusion).

BEA0B1FE8BD44574A5A6DD08429C0372.description: Examine and reflect on the practice of art-making in supporting one’s mental health and wellness.

87806F16CACA4A1583638E623C0603EC.description: Explore and experiment with new media, techniques, subject matter and ideas (e.g., apply knowledge of motion, body mechanics and figure modeling to digital animation software).

7EC9D8C457E647A1A89E2A7AA3B0DDAC.description: Follow Workplace Hazardous Material Information System (WHMIS) and art classroom safety guidelines.

1ACFBB6E89F445229B263378064B7CD3.description: Practise and refine processes and techniques for artistic intent.

AFF96A1FD92842539575402B0353F5E4.description: Investigate various ways of working and thinking associated with the creative process.

05F2A6497F014859B848DAC99A5E3821.description: Collaborate with peers to organize and curate a group exhibition based upon a central theme (e.g., classroom show, community show, online show, printed exhibition catalogue).

5FC3D1B53F6347079A4087071269DD0B.description: Exhibit confidence and commitment in expressing ideas visually.

2FD1D098117146A5906009DA923C2928.description: Represent understanding by applying learning in a new way (e.g., represent concepts from other areas of study, create artist statements, teach a technique to peers, younger students or a community group).

C215F6DE12524D21AE62322E7CE2ED4B.description: Demonstrate ability to innovate and take risks using familiar and unfamiliar art-making processes and techniques.

F62631E1E0454BDE96A61ED3BDA0BAEA.description: Evaluate own work to ensure respectful use of sources of inspiration and images (e.g., copyright, appropriation).

72C96980C15A4D1B89022BE4119D1D70.description: Explore Métis history, stories, traditions and visual art imagery as a way of opening a path to each student’s own historical story involving the importance and role of relationships, communities and family roots.

5C629FA2BFB5432ABEA37A1E1B7DA759.description: Engage with Indigenous and non-Indigenous artists to discuss art practices and apply new knowledge to own work, respecting cultural contexts.

7BB8D2D06F334265977DFDC66DF7F950.description: Engage with First Nations and Métis Elders, Knowledge Keepers, community leaders and artists to discuss how traditional and contemporary visual art practices (e.g., gifting of knowledge, protocols concerning use of images, issues of appropriation) influence the development of an artist’s personal voice.

A1B0857AE4534F9C80D811141DA1B436.description: Co-construct criteria for assessing and evaluating students’ voice, artistic growth and development.

F72D4B2B47A14A5B830985993391CC9A.description: Create art work expressing individual and/or collective voice concerning an issue of importance to students.

A8E5F4F361874327AB7F27A039AD679F.description: Demonstrate development, breadth and extension of an idea, context, and/or media through a series of works.

2F5258E0ADA14E09AF0E358FFC6DE4B9.description: Recontextualize or reuse everyday objects or styles to discover new layers of meaning for a desired effect.

B8E287C7B0DA4277964836C5723B5233.description: Demonstrate thoughtful reflection regarding the challenges and successes of risk-taking.

C1E1B7A285EB4C729132E5430B3E01DF.description: Follow Workplace Hazardous Material Information System (WHMIS) and art classroom safety guidelines.

581055EC7BDB45928D792EA3AAABAC73.description: Demonstrate risk taking with selected media to convey a sense of individual voice.

1E7D20660B084F9B8DD661D38FB768AE.description: Plan and refine own art work throughout the creative process (e.g., locate and use visual references, research, create maquette/model, conduct informal critique).

B0437D9F7C95445D84DDAE1006C97B68.description: Independently plan and create art works, in selected media and forms, demonstrating personal voice and artistic growth.

47DDDB86424E4CD2BABFD84B551CC51A.description: Document own work (e.g., sketchbook, portfolio) to support ideas and skill development.

6A767BB9DC2A41118A5C1F28979821A6.description: Collaborate with peers to develop criteria for critique.

7B8FA756D55349B882847FF9B11EA5D0.description: Explain (e.g., verbal, written artist statement, critique) how image development strategies were used, and how they and the media help to communicate meaning for self and viewer.

B9D22E7D06704F238E6A18FE068AFBA3.description: Identify technical strengths and areas that require further work and practise ways to improve (e.g., visual art journal).

17B35B7C0A934842B86FB8FD636B804C.description: Evaluate/critique own ideas and select the best to transform into a visual art product.

9363D321C07D4C06BC7A1DDB3CD9C1EE.description: Independently develop visual ideas and/or thumbnail sketches for original works of art (e.g., work may be based on the work of another artist but is not a direct copy of that work).

E753CF1F78A04442BC247832AC35E3D8.description: Select and apply design, composition and image development strategies to enhance personal voice and style, considering, for example: Elements of Art, Principles of Design and Sample Image Development Strategies

B7F8A39470614F00A747AE87D1723D06.description: Purposefully select and manipulate media and image development strategies to express ideas demonstrating personal style and voice.

3B34FCE8575E4375923FC3569211E015.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
